FAQ

 

For what purposes Technology Valuation is required?

·        Licensing

·        Sale of IP/technology

·        Mergers/Acquisitions

·        Infringement law suits

·        Financing/Securitization

·        Taxing/Reporting

·        Planning Strategy/R&D

 

What are The prerequisites of Valuation?

Understanding about:

–       Purpose of valuation (viz., for finalizing a transaction strategy, fixing a process; reporting, taxing; litigation);

–       Description of IP (type of IP: Patent, TM, Copy right, knowhow along with prosecution history, search report etc.);

–       Target (possible markets, market intelligence data)

–       Competing products and IP landscape

–       Novelty and USP of technology and State of IP filing

–       Regulatory requirements

–       Target market-acceptance, strategy

–       Bank rates, Royalty, Depreciation

 

What are the Methods for Technology Valuation?

There are two approaches for valuating an intellectual asset

–       (A) Qualitative (B) Quantitative.

•        Qualitative Methods: The qualitative methods include Patent indicators, Due diligence and Patent rating/ranking.

•        Quantitative Methods: The major approaches for real time valuation of IP are quantitative in nature and they generate the value of the IP in monitory terms

 

Which method shall I use in the Decision Support System?

(a)    Cost Method:

-        Most simple method

-        Advantageous for the Licensee

-        Generally underestimates the value

-        It sums up the costs incurred in developing the technology with some profit margin

-        Useful for products in the introductory stage in Life cycle

-        Appropriate for new and novel products with no competing products and no information about future markets

 

(b)    Market Method:

-        Appropriate for products/technologies with a lot of completion in market by similar product/technology

-        Useful for products in the maturity stage in Life cycle

-        Some market intelligence data required

 

(c)    Income Method

-        Two Types of Income method- (i) Royalty & (ii) Profit-Spilt

-        Appropriate for promising products/technologies with future markets

-        Useful for products in the growth stage in Life cycle

-        Some market intelligence data required

-        Advantageous for the Licensor/developer

-        Needs information about future cash flows, royalty rates, operational costs etc.

What are the advantages of using this DSS?

-        Can use the best method or get the average of all methods

-        The DSS can be used for any technologies developed within the National Agricultural Research System.

-        The technologies have been classified into 5 major segments- Crop Science, Horticulture, Agriculture Engineering &ICT, Animal Science and Fisheries. Each of these have been again sub-divided into 24 sub-categories ( Eg: Agriculture Engineering &ICT segment is further divided into 6 sub-categories viz., Machinery & Farm Equipment, Post-Harvest process & Products, Renewable Energy Gadgets, Irrigation & Water Management Equipment, Electronics, Software & DSS)

-        The software will fetch data from the data base if you don’t have specific data on royalty rate, depreciation, bank rate etc.

-        The output will be available in pdf format with all data and valuated amount.

-        The DSS can be further used for planning pricing, negotiation and marketing strategies.

How Royalty can be fixed?

Royalty is generally based on negotiated percentage that is fixed as per industry standards. The royalty rates can be finalized by referring websites - RoyaltySource.com, IPresearch.com, Consor – La Jolla, California (www.consor.com), RoyaltyStat (www.royaltystat.com) or reviewing the reports of big Accounting Firms, existing in-house licenses and infringement lawsuit awards.

A matrix based approach is developed for fixing the range of Royalty:

Parameter

Level 1

Level 2

Level 3

Level 4

Level 5

Demand Level

No existing demand (1)

Spurious demand (2)

Low demand (3)

Medium demand (4)

High demand

(5)

Customer Segment

Unidentifiable (1)

Identified and growing slowly (2)

Identified and small size (3)

Identified and moderate size (4)

Identified and huge size (5)

Technology

New and not tested (1)

New and tested but with marginal results (2)

New but positive results (4)

Existing and growing rapidly (5)

Existing and well established but not growing rapidly (3)

Product

New and not tested in the market (3)

New and tested but with marginal results(4)

New but positive feeling (5)

Existing (2)

Old product, re-launch (1)

Substitute Products

Numerous and very good (1)

Number fairly high (2)

Few and very good (3)

Few but with old technology (4)

No substitutes (5)

Strength of the patents

Low; Clustered  domain of patents (1)

Moderate; Numerous other patents (2)

Moderate; Few patents in the domain (3)

High; Few patents in the domain (4)

Very High; Are key patents (5)

Score: 15-20 Royalty: 3-5 % Score: <15 Royalty: < 3 %
